comments: This course relies on a variety of sociological perspectives to examine the role of the media and popular culture in everyday society, with a particular emphasis on the power of the mass media industry, the relationship between cultural consumption and status, and the social organization of leisure activities from sports to shopping. Specific course topics include the marketing of Starbucks, the rise of aesthetics and style in everyday life, the reception of film and rock music in contemporary American society, and the social effects of new media technologies in the digital age.  Overall, students found the content of this course “very interesting.” According to one student, “the concepts were well presented and appropriate in difficulty.” In the words of one student, “both the readings and ideas discussed in lecture seemed irrelevant in light of a changing media landscape.”  Opinions on Professor Grazian were mixed. Some students found him “incredibly knowledgeable,” calling him “an amazing lecturer” and “media savvy.” Others felt that lectures were “too scripted” and “not engaging” considering the course material. Many students felt that the TA’s were unhelpful and “difficult to communicate with.”  Several students voiced the concern that there was “an extreme amount of reading,” which was difficult to keep up with throughout the semester. This course is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.
